author: By Christian Mckay Heidicker
title: Invasion of the Memory Snatchers
description: In Kory Merritt’s “No Place for Monsters,” an invisible force is snatching kids in the night, erasing them not only from their beds but from everyone else’s memory.
content: Every neighborhood is haunted. Just ask its youngest residents. The window wells are goblin pockets. Demons perch on power lines. Hedges conceal toothy horrors. These monsters usually dissolve upon further inspection. But not in Cowslip Grove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: What the N.B.A.’s West Teams Need: Shooters and Shady Texts
description: It will take some teams more than one off-season to retool themselves into contention, but there is at least one thing each team can do to improve. Here are our suggestions.
content: Finally — finally — the N.B.A. off-season is here. Sure, it’s October, months removed from when the off-season would typically begin if there wasn’t a pandemic. And of course, the Los Angeles Lakers are still trying to figure out if they can throw a Zoom championship parade after conquering the Walt Disney World bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: ‘Please Like Me,’ Trump Begged. For Many Women, It’s Way Too Late.
description: The white suburban voters the president needs to carve a path to victory have turned away from him, for deeply personal reasons.
content: WESTERVILLE, Ohio — Kate Rabinovitch doesn’t call herself an activist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: At Least 3 Injured in Explosion at Virginia Strip Mall
description: The shopping center was a “complete loss,” a city official said. The cause of the explosion was unknown.
content: At least three people were taken to hospitals, two of them with serious injuries, after an explosion and fire on Saturday morning at a strip mall in Harrisonburg, Va., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.C. Shilton
title: Will we remember how hugging works when we are allowed to do it again?
description: As the weeks of coronavirus quarantine stretched into months, hugs are among the many things isolated people found themselves aching for. Hugs are good for humans — perhaps more valuable than many of us realized, until we found ourselves missing them.
content: As the weeks of coronavirus quarantine stretched into months, hugs are among the many things isolated people found themselves aching for. Hugs are good for humans — perhaps more valuable than many of us realized, until we found ourselves missing them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Rhonda Fleming, 97, Movie Star Made for Technicolor, Is Dead
description: Ms. Fleming’s roles ranged from Wyatt Earp’s love interest to a princess in King Arthur’s court.
content: Rhonda Fleming, the red-haired actress who became a popular sex symbol in Hollywood westerns, film noir and adventure movies of the 1940s and ’50s, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 17, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 17, 2020.
content: An article on Wednesday about a new philanthropic award misstated Edafe Okporo’s connection to the RDJ Refugee Shelter. He is its director, not its founder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel J. Pilgrim
title: The Long, Worthwhile Search for the Five Black Women of Grace Baptist Church
description: The names of the five Black founders of a church in Mount Vernon, N.Y., seemed lost to history — until a student journalist stepped in.
content: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y. — My family moved to Mount Vernon, N.Y., when I was 6. Our new home was several blocks from one of the city’s most recognizable buildings, Grace Baptist Church. Its gargantuan edifice, made of white brick and looming stained glass windows, was where I was baptized only a few months before our move, and it is the only church home I have ever known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Will Smith Homers Off Will Smith, and the Dodgers Top the Braves
description: Yes, you read that correctly.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — Now, this is a story all about how a game got flipped, turned upside down, and I’d like to take a minute, just sit right there, I’ll tell you how Will Smith became the prince (and goat) of Game 5.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sheet-Pan Cauliflower Readers Love
description: Make Melissa’s recipe, or any of the most popular recipes of the week.
content: This weekend make Melissa Clark’s roasted cauliflower with pancetta, olives and crisp Parmesan (above), Yasmin Fahr’s spicy butternut squash pasta with spinach or J. Kenji López-Alt’s chicken and cabbage salad with miso-sesame vinaigrette. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucinda Rosenfeld
title: Trick or Treat: It’s Mom and Dad!
description: The world’s worst parents come back to haunt us, in Lois Lowry’s “The Willoughbys Return.”
content: “The Willoughbys,” published in 2008 and recently adapted for animated film, opens with its fictional kids riffing on the fact that the main characters in so many classics of children’s literature, from “The Secret Garden” to “Anne of Green Gables,” are orphans. Thanks to their horrible and indifferent parents, the four Willoughby children are hoping to join the list. It’s one of several “meta” moments in the book, where the author seems simultaneously to be in dialogue with young readers and with the genre itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. records over 70,000 cases in one day for the first time since July.
description: More than 70,450 new coronavirus cases were reported in the United States on Friday, the highest figure since July 24, according to a New York Times database. More than 900 new deaths were recorded.
content: More than 70,450 new coronavirus cases were reported in the United States on Friday, the highest figure since July 24, according to a New York Times database. More than 900 new deaths were recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Suspect Stalked French School Before Beheading Teacher, Officials Say
description: The suspect, a Russian immigrant, was angered by a classroom display of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad and sought help identifying the teacher involved.
content: PARIS — The suspect in the beheading of a history teacher in a Paris suburb was an 18-year-old immigrant of Chechen descent who was angered by the classroom display of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, French officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Armenia, Azerbaijan Reach New Cease-Fire for Nagorno-Karabakh
description: A truce brokered just a week earlier failed to hold. The war between the two Caucasus countries has already killed hundreds.
content: GORIS, Armenia — Armenia and Azerbaijan agreed to a new cease-fire in their conflict over a disputed territory, the countries said Saturday, days after a truce negotiated a week earlier had unraveled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leonard Suryajaya and Laila Lalami
title: The Comforts of Clutter
description: Objects saved and accumulated can be a balm for uncertain times.
content: Except for my writing desk, where books, manuscripts, index cards and journals are piled in random fashion, I have always disliked clutter. I grew up in a large, chaotic household; at any time of day or night, someone was entertaining a friend or watching television or fixing a snack or hammering at a woodworking project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Bill Offering L.G.B.T. Protections in Italy Spurs Rallies on Both Sides
description: Supporters frame the measure as a long-overdue means to provide basic human rights. Opponents depict it as an overreaching step that would suppress opinion.
content: ROME — Protesters turned out in force on Saturday for rival demonstrations on a bill that would make anti-L.G.B.T. violence a hate crime carrying harsher penalties than under current law, coming out by the hundreds in Rome despite a resurgence of coronavirus cases in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Azi Paybarah
title: N.Y.C. Was Once a Bastion of G.O.P. Moderates. Then Trump Came Along.
description: For decades, Republicans in Manhattan carved out a niche by embracing socially liberal causes. President Trump’s election destroyed that centrism.
content: Over the course of two decades, the New York City Republican Party got two mayors elected in deep blue New York City. It was a neat trick made possible by the party’s ability to toe a centrist line — conservative on the budget, liberal on social issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael T. Luongo
title: Despite Everything, People Still Have Weddings at ‘Plantation’ Sites
description: Weddings help pay for education at American labor camp sites and connect us with history. Is that good enough?
content: The resurgence of the Black Lives Matter movement this spring spelled the end for many Confederate symbols. Monuments have been removed, by vote and by force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Hopkinson
title: The Women Behind the Million Man March
description: Behind every great feat in the public record lies an untold story of the unsung foot soldiers.
content: Just over 25 years ago, Louis Farrakhan, the head of the Nation of Islam, realized he needed help in his quixotic quest to summon a million Black men to the National Mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Astros Battle Back to Force a Game 7 Against the Rays
description: Tampa Bay will start Charlie Morton, a former Astro, in a do-or-die game Saturday night, hoping to avoid joining the 2004 Yankees as the only teams to lose a series after taking a 3-0 lead.
content: Charlie Morton threw the final pitch for the 2017 Houston Astros, perhaps the most notorious World Series champions in major league history. Morton never batted in Houston that season, so he never got a sign from a teammate banging on a trash can. But those who did, he knows, were dangerous hitters even without the illicit help, and they are proving it again in the American League Championship Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: U.S. Schedules First Execution of a Woman in Nearly 70 Years
description: Lisa Montgomery, the only woman on federal death row, was convicted of killing a pregnant woman and attempting to pass the baby off as her own.
content: A date has been set for the execution of a Kansas woman who was convicted of killing a pregnant woman and cutting the baby from her abdomen in what would be the first federal execution of a woman in nearly 70 years, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ed Benguiat, a Master of Typography, Is Dead at 92
description: A noted graphic designer, he was an expert in typefaces, developing many himself and “fixing” others. His work adorns this newspaper.
content: Ed Benguiat, a celebrated graphic designer known for his expertise in typefaces — including the one you see at the top of the print and web editions of this newspaper — started his design career in a not-so-celebrated post at a movie magazine publisher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nahid Siamdoust
title: A Musician Revered by Iranians, But Banned by the State
description: Mohammad Reza Shajarian’s politics were almost never explicit, but the Iranian people knew he stood with them.
content: Within minutes of the death of the Iranian vocalist Mohammad Reza Shajarian last week, thousands streamed into the streets surrounding his hospital in Tehran, openly wept and sang his songs in unison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: For Long-Term Investors, Small Things Like Presidential Elections Don’t Matter
description: There is heartbreak almost everywhere you look, our columnist says, but the stock market usually rises anyway.
content: In a year of serial crises, solace for many people has come from an unlikely source: the stock market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: Trump’s Nominee Gets a Hearing and the Town Hall Divide: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Supreme Court confirmation hearing unfolded on Capitol Hill while President Trump and Joe Biden participated in dueling town hall events.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Solomon
title: In My Mountain Town, We’re Preparing for Dark Times
description: As the contagion spreads, we look ahead to winter and wonder whom we can safely pull close.
content: TWISP, Wash. — At dawn the deer are as thick as cattle in the valley bottom, feeding on what remains after summer’s final haying. Soon, hunting season’s first shot will scatter them to higher country, where winds shake the aspens’ first golden coins to the ground. There’s not much time. So they eat the stubble without pause, fattening up for the hungry months ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: ‘White Supremacy’ Once Meant David Duke and the Klan. Now It Refers to Much More.
description: The phrase has poured into the nation’s rhetorical bloodstream. Organizations from the N.F.L. to art museums to colleges requiring the SAT are accused of perpetuating it.
content: As July 4 and its barbecues arrived this year, the activist and former N.F.L. quarterback Colin Kaepernick declared, “We reject your celebration of white supremacy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Sarah Mervosh and Marc Santora
title: As the Coronavirus Surges, a New Culprit Emerges: Pandemic Fatigue
description: Exhaustion and impatience are creating new risks as cases soar in parts of the world. “They have had enough,” one U.S. mayor said of her residents.
content: CHICAGO — When the coronavirus began sweeping around the globe this spring, people from Seattle to Rome to London canceled weddings and vacations, cut off visits with grandparents and hunkered down in their homes for what they thought would be a brief but essential period of isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: After Alabama Says Nick Saban Does Not Have Coronavirus, He Coaches a Game
description: The university said an earlier positive test result was false, after a series of negative tests. He led the team to a 41-24 victory over Georgia.
content: Nick Saban, the college football coach who revived Alabama into a national power, returned to work on Saturday — just in time for one of the most important games of the season — after doctors said that he had not been infected with the coronavirus after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden’s Non-Radical 1960s
description: Trump has called Biden a tool of leftist agitators. Friends say that has never much been his way, even as a young man surrounded by protest.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. marched into adulthood in Bass Weejuns penny loafers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Sacha Baron Cohen: This Time He’s Serious
description: Reviving his Borat character and playing the political activist Abbie Hoffman, the actor feels he “had to ring the alarm bell and say that democracy is in peril this year.”
content: Borat uses the flower bed in front of the Trump hotel at Columbus Circle as a men’s room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Federal Appeals Courts Emerge as Crucial for Trump in Voting Cases
description: Federal district courts have tended to rule for Democrats in litigation over how to run the election, but appeals courts, well stocked with the president’s nominees, are blocking them.
content: This month, a federal judge struck down a decree from Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas limiting each county in the state to a single drop box to handle the surge in absentee ballots this election season, rejecting Mr. Abbott’s argument that the limit was necessary to combat fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Tomasky
title: There’s a Word for Why We Wear Masks, and Liberals Should Say It
description: It’s high time Democrats played some philosophical offense on the concept of “freedom.”
content: Donald Trump is now back on the road, holding rallies in battleground states. These events, with people behind the president wearing masks but most others not, look awfully irresponsible to most of us — some polls show that as many as 92 percent of Americans typically wear masks when they go out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Fred Dean, Sack Specialist Who Ignited 49ers Dynasty, Dies at 68
description: Dean helped lead San Francisco to two Super Bowl victories, transforming the team into an N.F.L. powerhouse. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hillary Richard
title: Shh. It’s Breakfast Time.
description: Silent breakfast is a wellness practice that is helping some people cope with the pandemic.
content: “I don’t meditate so I look to other parts of my day to become meditative, including my coffee and breakfast routine,” Nina Zorfass, 30, a New York City resident who works in marketing, wrote in an email.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: In Kalamazoo, Old High School Classmates Reckon With a Divided Country
description: The Michigan city, like the state, is a battleground of cultural and racial tensions. I should know: I grew up there.
content: From a gauzy distance, Kevin Swift describes his high school years in the 1980s in Kalamazoo, Mich., as a carefree time of basketball games, English classes and beer parties. “We had it great there,” said Mr. Swift, who is Black and grew up in a majority-white neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Ernst Struggles in Iowa as Republicans Battle to Hold Senate Amid Trump’s Woes
description: Senator Joni Ernst, the first woman to represent Iowa in Congress, is facing the same headwinds plaguing President Trump, who is lagging in the state in part because of deep disadvantage among women.
content: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — The Toby Keith music blared from loudspeakers as Senator Joni Ernst, carrying an energy drink, worked a crowd of bikers in this town near the Nebraska border, shaking hands and giving out hugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Biden and Trump Say They’re Fighting for America’s ‘Soul.’ What Does That Mean?
description: The election has become a referendum on the soul of the nation.
content: It is a phrase that has been constantly invoked by Democratic and Republican leaders. It has become the clearest symbol of the mood of the country, and what people feel is at stake in November. Everyone, it seems, is fighting for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Make Your First Home Your Last: The Case for Not Moving Up
description: It’s a tough moment for big decisions. Think more about what you’ll want in three years — and not just three months, when we’ll still be shut in.
content: Home has become work and school for millions of people. Many residences needed to somehow shift overnight to accommodate two workplaces and multiple classrooms because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Where Liberal Power Lies
description: And why conservatives fear the creep of authoritarianism, too.
content: A striking thing about the current moment is that if you switch back and forth between reading conservatives and liberals, you see mirror-image anxieties about authoritarianism and totalitarianism, which each side believes are developing across the partisan divide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Man Sentenced to Life Over Theft of Hedge Clippers Is Granted Parole
description: Before 2017, a person in Louisiana could be sentenced to life in prison after receiving a fourth nonviolent conviction under the state’s habitual offender law.
content: A Louisiana man whose life sentence for attempting to steal hedge clippers in 1997 drew a national spotlight to the state’s habitual offender law has been granted parole, according to the Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: ‘How Weird Is All of This?’ Fans Return to a Warped Ballpark Experience
description: The National League Championship Series gave fans their first chance to watch M.L.B. action in person, but it wasn’t a typical stadium outing.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — For 54 consecutive years Mike Amodei attended at least one Dodgers game a season, beginning with a Sandy Koufax start in 1966. Nothing would ever stop him from keeping his streak alive, he thought — until a once-in-a-century pandemic put it in jeopardy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: For Young Rohingya Brides, Marriage Means a Perilous, Deadly Crossing
description: Girls and young women from refugee camps in Bangladesh, promised to men they have never met, are undertaking the dangerous journey to Malaysia to join them.
content: BANGKOK — Haresa counted the days by the moon, waxing and waning over the Bay of Bengal and the Andaman Sea. Her days on the trawler, crammed into a space so tight that she could not even stretch her legs, bled into weeks, the weeks into months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Diagramless
description: This Alex Eaton-Salners grid is not for the faint of heart.
content: DIAGRAMLESS — I have no bones to pick with diagramless puzzles from the past, but these new puzzles that make a picture when we finish them are really fun (never mind that I misinterpret what the picture is, sometimes). Today we have an October-relevant theme, beautifully presented by Alex Eaton-Jones, with some jaw-dropping geometry. It is easier than it looks, though, for one main reason: left/right symmetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: A Black Hole’s Lunch: Stellar Spaghetti
description: Astronomers observed a star become a “feast” for a cosmic monster.
content: Astronomers call it “spaghettification,” and it’s not a pretty idea: It’s what happens when you venture too close to a black hole and fall in. Tidal forces stretch you and break you like a noodle, then your shreds circle the black hole until they collide and knock each other in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josephine Wolff
title: How Ransomware Puts Your Hospital at Risk
description: In the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic, the potential consequences of cyberattacks are terrifying.
content: In March, several cybercrime groups rushed to reassure people that they wouldn’t target hospitals and other health care facilities during the Covid-19 pandemic. The operators of several prominent strains of ransomware all announced they would not target hospitals, and some of them even promised to decrypt the data of health care organizations for free if one was accidentally infected by their malware. But any cybersecurity strategy that relies on the moral compunctions of criminals is doomed to fail, particularly when it comes to protecting the notoriously vulnerable computer systems of hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Title Basin’
description: Go with the flow on this Miriam Estrin construction.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is a sweet, old-fashioned kind of solve from a new constructor, Miriam Estrin, who debuted back in June on a Saturday. I say this in regard to the theme, which is one of those classic road trip kind of tricks, but also because there are several entries in the fill that are endearingly nostalgic for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Jacinda Ardern, Hero to Liberals Abroad, Is Validated at Home
description: New Zealand’s prime minister and her party are coasting to victory in national elections, though it is unclear how far she will push her progressive promises.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Her face has graced magazine covers all over the world. Her leadership style has been studied by Harvard scholars. Her science-and-solidarity approach to the coronavirus has drawn legions of fans in other countries who write to say, “I wish you were here.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Inferno Threatens World’s Largest Tropical Wetland
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 17, 2020.
content: “I no longer hear the song of the Chaco chachalaca bird. Even the jaguar that once scared me is suffering.”
source.name: The New York Times
